intro: Acacia benthamii var. latior, commonly known as the broad-leafed acacia, is a shrub or small tree native to arid and semi-arid regions of Australia. It is characterized by its narrow, often fissured, dark grey to black bark and compound leaves composed of multiple pairs of small, narrow, leathery leaflets. The plant produces yellow globular flower heads, which are typically clustered in dense, rounded inflorescences. It is adapted to drought conditions and thrives in well-drained soils. Acacia benthamii var. latior is often used in revegetation projects due to its resilience and ability to stabilize soils in degraded landscapes.
distribution_native_art_desc: Acacia benthamii var. latior is primarily native to the arid and semi-arid regions of Western Australia. It is commonly found in the Pilbara and Gascoyne regions, where it thrives in sandy soils and coastal environments. This variant is adapted to withstand high temperatures and low rainfall, making it a resilient component of the local flora. It is often seen growing along rocky outcrops and in open woodlands. The plant plays an important role in the ecological balance of its native habitat.
distribution_introduced_art_desc: Acacia benthamii var. latior was mainly introduced to South Africa, where it has become naturalized in certain regions. It is commonly found in coastal areas and along roadsides, thriving in sandy soils. This plant is often used for erosion control due to its deep root system and ability to withstand harsh environmental conditions. However, it can become invasive in some areas, outcompeting native vegetation. Its introduction has raised concerns among conservationists due to its potential ecological impact.
